div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,549] ALEXANDRIA, Thursday, JULY 19, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe via Brindisi or via Maresilles £194.11.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The Engish Daily Newspaper, Established 1886
Editor and Manager - - R. SMELLING
ONE PLASTRE TARIFF
Thursday, July 19, 1906.
THE PRESS.

Mr. Harold Spender’s article, which we published in oar issue of yesterday, contrast curiously with Professor Flinders Petrie's summary of the situation in Egypt. The editor of the "Westminster Gazette" leaves his antiquarian rival far behind as far as style is concerned; but if we may adopt the ordinarily metaphor suggested by the title of his article he has made rather a hush of his deductions by the assumption that pigeons are regarded as more or less sacred by the fellaheen. Were this the tenth some of oar Egyptien confrères, who are now advocating the own version of the Japanese to Islam, would do well to send missionaries to the provinces of Egypt to check the growth of a dangerous superstition. Bat Mr. Spender does not realise—why should he! -that the causes of the Deuishwai outbreak (lie deeper. Professor Petrie has understood them clearly enough, and his quotation of the old adage, “Set a beggar on horseback and he will ride to the devil,’’ appears to us to explain the Danishwai outrage far better than any theories as to the persistence of pagan beliefs as exemplified in the reverence with which pigeons are said to be regarded by oar villagers. The fact is that, as we recently pointed out, the rural population has in pertain districts got ont of hand, owing to the absence of adequate penalties for perjury and assaults on the parson: criminals of a low mentality are more likely to be affected by any anti-foreign movement than any other section of the community, and the assertion that, beoanse the fellah does not read newspapers, he is therefore mentioned by the Pan-Islamio or Anti-Christian movement that has been preached by some of oar soi-disant Nationalists, falls, owing to this fact that some fellaheen read and that those who on read — oven with difficulty-generously supply their friends with the fruits of their erudition.
A column or two from "A1 Lewa” or “Al Umma,” painfully spelt out, goes a long way with ignorant peasants.

A Cairo cotemporary denies the statement chat “U Papagallo il Masti” has been suppressed. We hope the report to which we gave credence was founded on fact; otherwise we cannot bat think that toleration has been carried rather too far. After the Denishwai incident and the highly unpleasant symptoms which the frontier dispute with Turkey produced, tolerance is more likely than vigorous action to be ousted as a sign of weakness. Sir Edward Grey's warning and Lord Cromer's comments, recently published in the Bine-Book ladling with the frontier dispute, will appear rather brute fulmina -Anglioé, damp squibs —

(the reptile press is to be permitted to make capital out of the Deuishwai affair for no other purpose than that of inflaming fanaticism or anti-foreign feeling, between which, in a Moslem oouatry, the partition is unpleasantly thin.
No cases plague are repotted to day, but a recovery has taken place at Samalout.
On the 13th inst. the Coast Guards confiscated 132 kilos of hashish near the Suez Canal.
M. Nicolas E. Moussayas, pharmacist, and Mme Susanna Backmann, midwife, have been authorized to practice in Egypt.
During the past week 46 cases of cattle plague were noted throughout Egypt, viz., 6 cases at Tantab, 7 at Nawa, 32 at Fashn, and 2 at Tahta.

Alexandria’s first motor omnibus has al ready met with an accident. While on the Ramleh road yesterday it collided with a private automobile, the latter getting the worst of the impact. The chauffeur was slightly injured.

A Copt of Zawiet El-Masloub, Wasta Markaz, by nrme Barsoom Gbali, a few days ago be- came a pervert to Islam at the Mehkemeh Sharieh of Beni-Souef. The pervert expressed a wish to be known henceforth as ‘Mohamed Abdalla."

The San Stefano Casino have entrusted the management of the new theatre to M. Castellano, who has reunited a first class variety and ballet company, the first performance of which will be given on Saturday next at 9.30 p.m.

On the occasion of the Khedive's birthday (Monday, 23rd inst.) the usual reception will not be held. A register will be placed in the bureau of ceremonies at Ras-el-Tin Palace at the déposai of visitors who wish to enter their names that day.

The body of a native was found at 6 o’clock this morning floating in the Mahmoudieh Canal, near the El Haweea Customs quarter. It was taken out and sent to hospital for a post-mortem examination. No clue has yet -been found as to how the man met his death.

We have received a copy of Upton Sinclair’s sensational book ‘‘The Jungle,” published in Heiremann's Colonial Library. It is a remark- able novel, a novel with a purpose, which it has in a large measure achieved, and enohaina the readers' attention by the vividness of its pictures, the simplicity of the telling, and the entire absence of any attempt at teaching. 300,000 copies of the book have already been sold, and it has been translated into Frenob. It may be had in Cairo of Messrs. G. G. Zac- charia & Co., the English Library.

The annual exhibition and distribution of prizes took place in this school yesterday, Rev.H. P. Reid presiding. The programme, which consisted of English, French, Italian, and Arabic recitations and a cantata, “The White Garland,” was greatly appreciated by a large audience of parents and friends. The excellent entertainment reflected great oredit on Mrs. Gibb. Mrs. Davies Bryan presented the prizes to the successful pupils, amongst whom we specially mention Sarina Haber, of the senior class, who won the medal annually presented by Major Allen for Scripture knowledge. A second medal for the same subject was won by Fanny Levy, of the junior class.

div.head: DEATH OF LADY CURZON.
div.p: London, July 18.
Lady Curzon is dead. She had been suffering from complications, a sequel to her illness of two years ago.

Lady Curzon of Kedleston (» Mary Victo- ria Leiter) was born at Chicago, and the daughter of the late L. Z. Leiter, a plutocrat of that city. Her great talents and beauty, which had already made her one of the most popular debutantes in Washington society in 1891, added to the interest excited by the announcement of her engagement to the Hon. G. N. Curzon, and her marriage to him in 1895, in which year her husband became Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. In 1899 she accompanied her husband to India. As wife of the Viceroy she had naturally enough to contend with certain jealousies aroused by her American origin or by the unpopularity of the Viceroy among a certain section of Anglo-Indian officials, both military and civil. That she succeeded in overcoming them was a great testimony to her ability and personal oharm. She fulfilled the onerous social duties of her position with remarkable taot and graciousness, and the news of her serious illness twc years ago caused a widespread expression of sympathy. General regret will be felt at her death, and not least in Cairo, where she was with her husband the guest of Lord and Lady Cromer as lately as the 26th November last.

div.head: THE FRONTIER COMMISSION.
div.p: REPORTED DISAGREEMENT.
(From our correspondent.)

The delegates of the Mixed Commission are still at Rafah, and I understand that the Ottoman delegates are awaiting instructions from Constantinople before finally signing and accepting the maps showing the boundary line from Akaba to Rafah as defined and proposed by the Anglo Egyptian Commissioners. Hence the delay in the return of the latter to Egypt.

"Al Ahram” learns from its correspondent at El Areesh that the members of the Boundary Commission are still at Rafah owing to some differences which have arisen between the Egyptian and Ottoman delegates in regard to the boundary line.

H.H. cruiser Abd el Moneim, which reoeutly left for Rafah to convey the Egyptian dele- gates back to Port Said, has been sent back by the Egyptian members of the Commission, who are busy adjusting the points of disagreement.
Ahmed Bey Tewfik, Governor of El Areesh, has retnrned to bis Gonvernorat from Rafab, where he paid a visit to the Commission, of which his brother, Ibrahim Pasha Fathi, is a member.

div.head: FAITH IN ENGLAND.
div.p: Sayid Hassan Bey El-Akkad, a notable of Cairo, who has long been known as one of the native leaders who appreciate the British Occupation in Egypt, publishes a statement in the native Press, three columns in length, severely criticizing "Al-Mokattam” for ascribing religious fanaticism to the Egyptian people and threatening the Egyptians with severe measures. Sayid El-Akkad concludes as follows: "Consequently, I have to advise my brethren the Egyptians to put full confidence in the British Government, which does not intend to do them any harm, but on the contrary wishes them every prosperity. England is just and wise and it is unreasonable to suppose that she will ever demolish with her own hands in a day the proud and splendid fabric of reform which she founded, r quarter of a century ago, on the basis of justice and freedom. Let us all show Tmrpelves quiet and peaceful ; let ns put aside all useless agitation. As for ‘Al-Mokattam,’ which speaks in the name of the Occupation of Egypt, that journal has no private relations with the occupante, as the simple are led to imagine.”

div.head: ISLAM IN JAPAN.
div.p: he Rabbi Farag Mizrahi, of Alexandria, writes to “Al-Minbar” to say that two days ago he received a letter from a friend of his in Japan stating that the Japanese were now busily engaged in taking notes from both the Bible and the Koran with a view to discover religious principles: “The Japanese are inclining to the belief that there is but one God ; and the majority of the learned and heads of religions in Japan undoubtedly lean towards Islam.” Wo may contrast with this statement the remark recently made to an interviewer by the Marquis Ito—himself an agnobtic, by the way: “Whatever may be urged against our reli- gion, I hardly think we are likely to exobaDge it for any other creed, or that we have any reason to be ashamed of its fruits.”

div.head: THE DENISHWAI INCIDENT.
div.p: RADICALS HARASSING SIR E. GREY.

The Radical members of Parliament exhibit a persistence in their cross-examination of Sir Edward Grey regarding the Denishwai affair that is worthy of a much bettèr object'than they have in view. Mr. J. MaoVeagh asked the Secretary for Foreign Affaits upon what evidence the assertion of unrest in Egypt at the present time was based ; and whether be would furnish a return showing the number of prosecutions and convictions for offences of violence against members of the Army of Occupation and European civilians during the last five years. Sir E. Grey : I cannot undertake to have such a return prepared. The statements I have made are based upon confidential reports received from his Majesty’s representative at Cairo, extending over several months. y Mr. MacVeagh asked under what section of the Native Penal Code or the Special Decree of 1895 the sentence of flogging was passed in the Deuishwai oases. Sir E. Grey : By Article 5 of the Decree of 1895, the special tribunal has full power to inflict whatever punishment is èaosjdered necessary without reference to the ordinary penal code. A translation of the decree including this article will be included in the papers which have been promised. Mr. Belloo asked whether this tribunal had power to torture. Sir E. Grey replied that he was going to lay a translation of the deoree before the House, and any question with reference to it could be raised afterwards. Mr. J. Robertson asked whether it was not the case that the officers and soldiers concerned had not been acting as members of the Army. Sir E. Grey said he was not aware of that. Mr. MaoVeagh asked if the officers were acting in their capacity as private individuals. Sir E. Grey replied that they were in uniform, and therefore could not be considered as private individuals. Mr. MacVeagh: Were they committing an illegal act in uniform 1 Sir E. Grey: No, they were not committing an illegal act. (Cheers.) In reply to further questions by Mr. Mao- Veagh, Sir E. Grey said Lord Cromer, on receipt of an application irom the genera) officer commanding, requested the Ministry for Foreign Affairs to summon the Special Tribunal provided tor by the Decree of 1895. It has not been suggested that the officers were guilty of trespass. The Special Tribunal was instituted to take the place of courts- martial ; to ensure that oases of this nature should be tried by competent judges ac- quainted with the country, customs, and language of the people; and, at the dame time, to prevent any possible miscarriage of justice, by giving greater security to the accused than they would have had if tried by courts-martial. Boutros Pasha was for many years Under-Secretary of State at the Minis- try of Justice. I am not aware whether he has previously officiated as a judge in a criminal case, but he is acting Minister of Justice in the absence of the latter, and as such necessarily presided over the Court. At the trial, after each witness had been heard, counsel for the defense were invited by the Court to put any questions they pleased. This is in accordance with the hope of criminal procedure in Egypt. He hoped to present the papers in a fortnight.

The "Figaro” publishes a letter of protest from Mustapha Pasha Kamel ccuoerning the Denishwai incident. Kamel Pasha deokres, ‘ in the name of all that is sacred on earth,” that there is no ground whatever for the statement made in the House of Commons by Sir Edward Grey with regard to toe existence of religious fanaticism in Egypt. “Sir Edward Grey,” he says, “has been led into error. If religious fanaticism existed in Egypt, how would it have been possible for fifty-two Mussulmans to be tried by a court composed of four Christians and only one Mussulman 1 Those who live in Egypt and •possess any love for the truth knowery well that the Denishwai affair was not an anti- European movement. We daim in itioe, equality, and liberty, and we desire to have a Constitution giving us full power over our own affdrs. The friends of liberty in England ought to expeot, as we do, that Egypt, which has given to the world its highest civilization, shall not be a field of barbarity, but a country where civilization and justice shall be as fruitful as the earth.” In publishing Kamel pasha’s article the "Figaro” says : "We have not thought it right to refuse the distinguished chief of the Egyptian Nationalist Party the publication of his appeal against the somewhat summary proceedings of English justice. But is Le himself sure of the impartiality of his judgment against the English, and what other guarantee to his own words can he bring to convince us that Sir E. Grey was wrong in his recent speech, when he referred to the possibility of a disquieting awakening of Mohamedan fanaticism 1 The agitation which has for some time teen prevalent in Egypt, the Tabah affair in which Mnstapha Kamel Pasha admits the Nationalists were on the side of Turkey, the present run of events in Tripoli, the recent events in Morocco, and the unsettled conditions even in the depths of Africa all tend to show that, on the contrary, Sir E. Grey was well advised in requesting his Radical friends to refrain from making any demonstration which in any way could calculated to encourage fanaticism.”

div.head: CAIRO HOTEL COMBINE.
div.p: HITCH IN NEGOTIATIONS

At the meeting which took place in Paris last month between Qeorge Nungovi ch Bey and Mr. Charles Baehler, we understand that the negotiations oame to nothing, and that the proposals to amalgamate the varions hotels of the Nangovioh and Egyptian Hotels Companies are consequently in abeyance.
COMMERCIAL AGREEMENT SIGNED.

H. E. Bontros Pasha Ghali, Minister for Foreign A flairs, and Marqois Salvsgo Raggi, Italian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General in Cairo, have signed the commercial agreement concluded recently between Italy and Egypt, after two years’ negotiations.
FEELING IN GERMANY.

The semi-official reassurances published in Germany with regard to the probable effect on German interests of the Abyssinian Agreement are received in a somewhat skeptical spirit by many organs of the Press, which according the "Morning Post’s” Berlin correspondent, construe the co-operation of Italy with France and Great Britain as a fresh diplomatic defeat for Germany. The “Tageszeitung” bitterly observes that Signor Tittoni is wiser than was M. Delcassé, in that he nas imparted to his policy an appearance of formal correctness by communicating its details to the German and Austro- Hungarian Governments. The Agrarian organ ascribes to the new arrangement farreaobing political consequences. Italy, it says, has pro- fitted one more by the permission accorded her to indulge in an "extra dance." Her accord with Great Britain and France may now bd considered perfect, and henceforth the inter- national situation will he governed by the existence of a triple alliance between the ally of Germany and the Western Powers. "What asks the “Tageszeitung,” "will he the future attitude of Italy towards Germany I” It proceeds to answer this question by in- sinuating chat the statesmen on the Tiber will refrain from committing the blunder with which Chancellor Caprivi inaugurated his assumption of office. They will endeavor to hold fast to their reinsurance Treaty and to the Triple Alliance, knowing full well that Germany, under existing (conditions, is pledged to protect their country drum the aggression of other States, whereas they do not intend to fulfil, in the event of war, their obligations towards Germany. This being so, France and Great Britain can have no objection to Italy remaining a member of the Triple Alliance. Germany, however, concludes the "Tageszeitung,” will not evince much anxiety to renew a treaty of which she has tonier all the costs while Italy reaps all the advantages. The “Kolnisohe Volkszeitong.’’ the chief organ of the Raman Catholic party, publishes an article in which it expresses the conviction I that Italy will tacitly cease to be a member of I the Triple Alliance, bat that her secession will not be publicly admitted for a long time to come.

A meeting was held last week at the offices, London-wall, to confirm the resolution passed on the 2Stb nit. for the voluntary liquidation of the company and the appointment of Mr. G. T. Broadbridge (the secretary) as liquidator. Mr. R. Logan presided, and moved the confirmation of the resolution, which was seconded by Mr. C. C. Perkins. A discussion followed in regard to the arrangement arrived at for amalgamating with the Building Lands of Egypt (Limited) ; and in reply to questions the chairman said that the shares of that company were now folly paid aud this company was to receive 60,000 share", £4 paid, in exchange for 200,000 shares of £1 paid. They would therefore receive a nominal value of £240,000, eonal to a boons of 20 percent. The shares were of £4 each because that was the denomination dealt in on the Egyptian Bourse. The motion was agreed to, and a farther resolution was passed sanctioning the distribution of the 60,000 shades pro rota among the shareholders. Mr. Broadbridge stated that he would make the distribution as soon as the share certificates arrived from Egypt— in the course of a few weeks he expected.

div.head: THE FASHN TRAGEDY.
div.p: A telegram received by Christo Nioolaou, brother-in-law of the woman murdered at Fasbn, as already reported in our columns, reports that on Tuesday his uncle, Yanni Toutourli, had been murdered. It was he who,according to onr information, first Buspeoted Spiro Cotta as being the murderer of Mme Nicolaou. It is necessary to recapitulate the whole history, of which we are in possession, and of which this latest murder is the sequel. The late Spire Nicolaou was a cotton-seed dealer, and he had matried a Mile Cotta, sister to the brothers Lambro and Sotiri Cotta, of Alex- andria, who resided at 16, Sesostris-street, and have a business at Shibin el Korn. On the 14th March, Spiro Nicolaou, who snffered from his lungs, came down to Alex- andria and was admitted to the nativehospital, much against thè^wishea of his wife, who would have preferred to send him abroad, and declared that the Cottas were too mean, although they had the money, to comply with her wish. As it was, Spiro Nikolaou succumb- ed to an operation in hospital. His will, which he made on bis death-bed, left all his money to his wife and brother, and an annuity of 25 pounds to hia mother. This gave great umbrage to the Cottas, who made out that h:s wife had prevailed upon him to make out the will in her favour. A quarrel ensued, and a lawsuit followed, which necessitated Christo’s presence at the Court of Alexandria. The Patriarchate of Alexandria, pending the judgment of the Consular Court, sealed the property of the deceased man.
The Scene of the Crime.

The dwelling occupied by the Nioolaou family was one common to Egyptian country life. It was in two storeys, the mandra being oc- cupied by the counting house and store-rooms for the cotton seed, and the upper rooms being occupied by the family. Ahmed Gomaa, who has now disavowed his guilt, was in the employ of the late Spiro Nioolaou. He seems to have been the agent of Cotta, who paid him various sums of money to win him over. He is a fellah Af the ordinary type. Spiro Cotta, who absolutely denied even knowing Gomaa, was an Ottoman subjeot who, originating from Koritza, in Macedonia, ob- tained recognition from the Egyptian Govern- ment four years ago as a Helleuio subjeot The Consular authorities give a complete denial by our informant that ha is a Turkish subject or Rayah. Cotta lived at an inn of Fashn.
How the Crime was Committed.

Although he now completely disavows having committed the orime, Gomaa gave be- fore the authorities of Minieh a detailed description of how the deed was carried out, a description which ciroamstantial evidence wholly bears out. On the night of the 25th June Cotta met him, and said he wished to speak to him. They went off together, and Cotta told him that he wanted toJrillMme Nioolaou, offering him one hundred pounds to do it Gomaa oonsented and they returned to the house. On the way they were met by the ghaffir", who, however, knowing Gomaa to belong to the place, did not question the pair. As the women were still awake when they arrived, they waited below in the mandra. It was late when the two began their horrid work. Armed with a kitchen knife and a sleeve dagger, they soaled the wall and reached the window of the room where the woman and her niece, a girl of fourteen, slept. The woman was the objeot of their attack. Gomaa seized her first and dealt her a stroke in the neck,but before he could finish her. her startled ories had roused her niece, who closed on Gomaa from behind. Cotta here interfered, and leaving the Arab to deal with the girl, cat the throat of the woman, who rolled under the bed. Tbé girl was similarly dispatched and fell beside the door, where the next morning she was found hud- dled up. The ghastly work done, Cotta paid Ahmed the sum of thirty pounds which he fonnd in the room, and promised the remaining seventy the next day. He then returned to the hotel. The next morning, when the whole plaoe was in an uproar, Cotta was fonnd fast asleep in bed, in 1rs clothes, and with his registration paper in his pocket as if ready for flight. Moreover, be seemed exceedingly merry and pleased with himself. When confronted with the corpses, he said nothing, bnt changed connteDanoe. At Alexandria, before the Con- sular Court, he denied completely all Gomaa had said but afterwards seemed to be much affected, so much so that the Consul asked the reason. "I don’t know,” was all he said. Gomaa and he are still under lock and key, and the enquiry is proceeding.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
Jerusalem, July 16.

Mr. Freeman, late H.M.’s Vice-Consul at Alexandria, is expected here to-morrow to take charge of the consulate pending the appointment of a suecessor to the late Consul Dickson. The Sultan has conferred the Grand Cordon ot the Osmanieh in brilliants on H.E. Rashid Boy, Governor-General of Palestine, and the secoud olass of the same Order on Béchara EfTandi Habib,direotenr politique and secretary of the Mateseariiat of Jerusalem.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Mr. and Mrs. Longwortb (nee Roosevelt) are expeoted to pay a visit to‘Egypt, after visiting Constantinople. On leaving Paris they will proceed to Belgium, and will visit Brussels and Antwerp. They will be received by King Leopold.
The Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agent, Count T. Bolesta de Koeziabrodzki, has arrived at Alexandria from Cairo.
El Lewa Mansfield Pasha, Commandant of the Cairo City Police, has postponed his departure on leave till the 11th prox., owing to the slight indisposition of Mrs. Mai afield.

Major-General J.M. Grierson, C.B., who is about to vacate the Direotor-Gener dship of Military Operations at the War Office, to take command of the 1st Division at Aider- shot, in succession to Lieut-Generd A. H. Paget, commenced in the Royal Artillery in 1877, his first aptive service being with the expedition against Arabi Pasha in 1882, when he acted as. deputy-assistant quarter- master-general at Kassassin am Tel-el-Kebir. Subsequently he took part m the Sudan oampaign of 1888 and the Hazara operations three years later. In 1896 he was appointed military attaché at Berlin, relinquishing that post on‘becoming assistant adj'ntant-general in Sonth Africa during the late war. In 1900 he received the Military Companionship of the Bath for his servioas in China, and after hold- ing many important staff positions was raised to the rank of major-general two years ago.
Lieut. R. Lamb, R.A., has arrived from England and been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bimbashi. He has been posted to the 15th Sudanese.
El Bimbashi T. F. Murray, 9th Sudanese, has been transferred to the 1st Battalion, and El Bimbashi A. L. Hadow, Upper Nile district, to the 9th Sudanese.

The marriage of Mlle Hélène Lunghi to Mr. John P. Schilizzi will take place at the Evan- gelismos Cathedral on Sunday, 29th inst., at 5.30 p. m. A reception will afterwards be held at the residence of the bride’s mother, Maison Zouro, 2, rue de l’Hôpital Egyptien.
Abdul Az'z Eff. Zjki, Sami Eff. Guridini, and William Eff. Berbari have been authorised to praotise as advooates before the Native Tribu- nals.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy, Port Said, we notioe Major Coutts, Jackson Pasha, Lt.-Col. Roper, Capt Protheroe-Smith Count von Bernsdorf, Dr. and Mrs. Borohard, Cattau'i Bey, Mr. Bowill, Mr. D. Klat and family, Mr. and Mrs. David, Miss Bird, Mr. Mr. Monz, Mr. S. de Bilinsky, Mr. Holmann, Dr. Moeller, Dr. Paul Knuth.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
Le Caire, Mercredi 18 Juillet 1906.

Hier, an Stock Exchange, le Consolidé An- glais est resté invarié à 88, son prix de clôture de la veille. L’Unifiée est demeurée inchangée à 105, de même que la National Bank k 25 1/8, l’Agriéole k 9 5/8, la Daira k 16 3/4 et la Delta Light k 11 8/4.
A Paris, l’aotion Crédit Foncier Egyptien est restée stationnaire k 751. La Banque d’Athè- nes a regagné 1 franc k 151.

Le mouvement de reprise que nous avions prévu ponr oette semaine dans notre Circulaire da vendredi passé s’est nettement dessiné ce mutin. Les meilleures dispositions se sont ma- nifestées, dès le débat de la séance, dans tons les compartiments da marohé, notamment dans celai des valeurs dirigeantes. L’animation a été vire, les transactions nombreuses, et il en est résulté.one plus-value appréciable sur la géné- ralité de la opte.

La National Bank, très mouvementée, a passé de 25 5/16 k 25 1/2 9/16. L'Agrioole s progressé à 9 11/16 3/4. La Cassa di Sconto a haussé k 223-224 l’aotion ancienne, et 217 la nouvelle. La Banque d’Orient s’est raffermie k 183. Le Comptoir Financier s’est insorit k 6 3/16-1/4 l’aotion anoienne et 5 5/16 la nou- velle.
L’aotion Crédit Fonoier est remontée k 760. L’obligation k lots 1886-a e'ôtnré k 328.
L’aetion Immobilière a avanoé k 372-375 ; la part de fondateur a atteint 675-680.
iL’aetion Entreprise et Travaux a été recher- chée k 4 ; la part de fondateur a progressé k 66-67.
L’aotion Allotment a gagné 1/16 k 3 7/16- 1/2 et la part de fondateur a o'Otnré k 124, après «voir atteint 128.
La part de fondateur Agricole du Nil a fléchi k 8 3/4.

La Delta Light s’est raffermie k 11 13/16 7/8. Les jouissances Baux du Caire Ont gagné 2 francs k 263. L'action Brasseries des Pyra- mides a fait 122, et la part de dividende’62. Les Ciments se sont insorits k 68-69 et la Frigorifique k 4 7/8-5.
L'aotion Héliopolis a été ootée 288 289, et la partdefondateur'demandée à 8 7/8. L’ao- tion Gharbieh s’est maintenue à 3 3/4 et la part de fondateur a été reoherohée à 1 7/8.
Dans le groupe, 'des Hôtels, les Nongovich ont été poussés à 15 15/16-19, et les Egyptian (Baohler) à 5 3/4-13/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont remonté & 31/2-9/16, les Estates à 1 8/4 13/16 et leur part de fondateur à 10 3/4. Les Salts and Soda ont repris à 19 sh. 6, et les Constructions à 1 1/4-5/16. Le Cotton Mills soqt revenus k 5 sh. 6.
L’assemblée générale extraordinaire de la Delta LandiCo.,, aura lieu demain è Londres.

Ce.melting promet d’être intéressant, car, en dehors de :1a' fusion aveo l’Egyptian Land and General Trust .(Hooker) il aura à se pro- noncer sur 4e projet d'augmentation du capital, ainsi que sur diverses modifications impor- tantes sur statuts.
Celles-ci semblent avaoir pour objet de ren- dre la Delta Land Co., indipendante de la Delta L'ght Relways Co., dont elle est la filiale.

Ea d’autres termes, le programme primitif de la Société serait modifié, en oe sens que la Delta Land ne se bornerait plus à acquérir des terrains à proximité des lignes existantes ou à créer de la Delta Light: elle aurait la fuoulté d’étendre un peu partent ses opéra tion en Egypte, et spécialement au Soudan.
C’est même dans cette dernière vne qne les administrateurs demanderaient l’autori- sation de porter éventuellement le oapital social de £250/000 k £600,000.

Le mouvement de hausse qui s’est produit ces jours derniers son les notions de la Cassa di Soonto e di Risparmio a été attribué à une rumeur suivant laquelle le conseil d'adminis- tration de cet établissement de crédit aurait décidé d’augmenter le oapital social au moyen d’une nouvelle émission d'actions, oonformé ment à ('autorisation qui lui aurait été ac oordée par la dernière assemblée générale extraordinaire des actionnaires.
Or, d’après les informations que nous avons pu obtenir, cette résolution serait bien dans l’srdre des choses possibles, mais elle n’aurait pas été jusqu’ici officiellement prise.
Les reoettesdes Tramways d’Alexandrie pour la semaine finissant au 14 Juillet oourant te sont é'evées à LE. 1,784, oontre 1,624 en 1905, soit one augmentation de L E. 160.
Depuis le 1er. Janvier 1906 les recettes ont atteint L. B. 40,248 oontre 33,891 pour la période' correspondante de l’exeroioe précédent. La piae-valoe totale se chiffre dono par L. E. 6,357.

American Futures.—The Market this week has exhibited the same dull aud inanimate oonditioD ss for some weeks past. Thera have been various minor fluctuations, but no deoided tendency, anchthe state of the market absolute ly reflects this indecision, and the oonBequent absenoe of speculation. To-day's closing values are 4 j points higher for Old Crop, aud 6 points higher for the New Crop positions, than those of last Thursday. Crop acoounte generally are oonsidered to be very favorable, although there have been some complaints of excessive rains again over a portion of the Atlantio States but they have not attracted muoh attention so far. Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc

div.head: NATAL ‘ OPERATIONS.
div.p: Durban, July J8.
The forces in the field have been greatly reduced. (Feuter)
Pietermaritzburg, July 18.
The oharges of massacre have been debated npon in the Assembly. The Minister of Publia Works, in defence, reiterated his denial that acta of barbarism had been committed. (R.)
London, July 19.

House ok Commons. —An animated debate took place with reference to the alleged atrooi- tiea in Natal. Mr. W. Chnrohill read a loDg reply from the Natal Government denying the charges but tbs Radicals pressed tbs most searching questions, demanding that the Im- perial Government should prohibit the employ- ment of native levies. The Liberal papers consider that the charges have been insuf- ficiently refuted and demand the appointment of an Imperial Commission with a view to the punishment of the guilty. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIA.
div.p: St. Petersburg, Jaly 18.
Agrarian disturbances expend over two hnn- dred versts of the province of Voroness. Land- owners are fleeing.
Admiral Skrydloff has been appointed suc- cessor to Admiral Chnkhnin. (Reuter)
St. Petebsburq, July 18.
The report of the Agrarian Committee of the Dama recommends the rejsotion of the Government programme. (Bavai)

div.head: EDUCATION BILL.
div.p: COMMITEE STAGE CONCLUDED.
London, Joly 18.

House ok Commons.—An exciting debate took place on Classe No. 37 of the Ednoation Bill, establishing the1 Welsh Bdnoation author- ity, styled the Connoil of Wales. Mr. Lloyd Qeorge intimated, in response to Unionist oritioisms, that the Government was prepared to appoint a Minister tor Welsh Education. The proposal was oarried by 379 votes to 50. The olanse was adopted by 395 votes to 107. (Reuter)
London, July 18.

House of Commons.—The committee stage of the Bdnoation Bill was conolnded yesterday evening, bnt many important points will oome np for disonssion in the report stage. It is expected that the measure will be finally dis- posed of on the 30:h instant. (Rmtar)

div.head: FIGHTING IN CENTRAL AMERICA.
div.p: GREAT SLAUGHTER.
New Yobk, July 18.

Severe fighting, with great slaughter on both sides, has taken plaoe between Goatemela and San Salvador. President Roosevelt has induoed the belligerents to agree to an armis- tice in order to appoint peace commissioners who will meet on board the American cruiser Marbltheid. (ReuterI

div.head: KING AND CANADA.
div.p: VISIT IMPOSSIBLE.
London, July 18.

The King has declined with regret Canada's invitation to visit that country. His Majesty alluded to the extent of the Empire and the importance of affairs of State, which necessitat- ed his being within easy reaoh of the oentre. (Reuter)

div.head: ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATION OF TSAR’S AIDB-DE CAMP.
div.p: St. Petebsbubg, July 19.
An attempt has been made to assassinate Count Tcdleben, aide-de-camp to the Tsar, in a camp near here. His assailant escaped in a boat which was waiting in the Neva. (Reuter)

div.head: ATLANTIC FLEET.
div.p: London, July 18.
Rear-Admiral Gedrge Le Clerc Egerton, C.B., bas been appointed second in command of the Atlantic Fleet. (Reuter)

div.head: GENERAL PICQUART.
div.p: Paris, July 18.
General Picqnart has been appointed com- mandant ad interim of the IOfb Division. (B.)

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: London, July 19.
Cricket. Worcestershire beat Northampton- shire by 21 runs at Northampton.
Yorkshire beat Derbyshire by 10 wiokets. Sussex heat Hampshire by an innings and 9 tons.
Kent beat Essex by 72 rune. ( Reuter)

div.head: MR. HALDANE’S SCHEME IN BRIEF.
div.p: Summarised, Mr. Haldane’s soheme for the re organisation of the British Army, presented to the Honse of Commons last Thursday, is as follows :
, The regular forces to be reduced by 20,000 men.
The cavalry not to be reduced.
The yecmaniy to supply a portion of the ex- peditionary force.
The horse artillery to remain as at present.
Thirty-six batteries of field artillery to bo converted to a militia basis for purposes of training and the supply of drafts.
Instead of only 42 batteries being available on mobilization there will be G3.
The infantry rednctione will be as follow : Two battalions of Gnards and eight of the Line to be dispensed with, namely :
3rd, Scots Gnards.
3rd Coldstreams.
3rd and 4th Northumberland Fusiliers.
3rd and 4th Royal Warwioks.
3rd and 4th Lancashire Fusiliers.
3rd and 4th Manchester Regiment.
Irish Gnards battalion to be reduced from 920 to 820.
After its re organization the Home Army will consist of 150,COO men, as under -
Regulars ... 50,000
Reservists 70,000
Men trained on Militia lines 30,000
Militia battalions to be reviewed, weak ones knocked off and consolidated, and the Militia artillery to bo converted into an ammunition column and artillery reserve.
Work not requiring the highest military skill to be done by men trained on a Militia basis, a reform from which considerable saving ii ex- pected.
Redactions to be made gradually ; no men to be turned into the streets.
The changes in the Militia artillery alone are expected to effect a saving of £ 300,000 a year.
The terms of enlistment onder Mr. Haldane’s scheme will be :—
Line and Cavalry: Seven years with Colours, five with Reserve.
Field Artillery : Six years with Colours, six with Roserve.
Garrison Artillery: Eight years with Colours, font with Reserve.

Under the new arrangements the 156 batta- lions tf the line will be reduced to 148. They will te distributed as follows : 58 in India, 25 in the Colonies, and 71 at home. This means a redaction of seven in the Colonies and one at home.
The Volunteers are to be given the old 15- ponnder gnna, converted to qniok-firers, to enable them to organize themselves into a national artillery reserve.
The Volunteers are also to be organized for the defenoe of naval porta and given definite fnnotions in each district
There will be no inoreased expenditure on the Volunteers.
There are at the present time 63 batteries of Field Artillery serving at home, whilst six others cow in Sonth Aftioa are to retnrn at an early date.

Of the present 99 batteries, 81 are to be kept on a four-gnn basis, the remaining 18 on a two gun basis,thns reducing the aotual number of gnns by 234, or a total of 39 batteries on the old six-gun basis.

Of the 81 new four-gun batteries, 63 only will be required for the expeditionary foroe of 6 Divisions The remaining 18 are to be utilized for training purposes on a Militia basis, as also the 18 two-gun batteries.

div.head: ANCIENT EGYPTIAN ART AT KING’S COLLEGE.
div.p: The old idea that it was only the Germans and the French who understood the art of arcbicologioai exploration will certainly be dispelled from the mind of any lover of the Orient who may visit tbe splendid collection of objects now exhibited by thé Bgypt Explora- tion Fond at King’s College. Victors to Egypt mast all be acquainted with tfie famous temple of Hathor, at I)éir el Bahri, near Thebes, tbe magnificent monument of tbe pride of Queen Hatshepsu, tbe Elizabeth of Egypt. For sixteen years that learned archaeologist and scholar, M. Edouard Naville, D.C.L , has continued to labour in clearing tbe huge edifice, restoring fallen sonlptnres to their plaoes, and oopying sculptures and inscriptions. The great temple of the eighteenth dynasty, bnilt about 1500 b c, has been rescued from the rain of centu- ries, and now stands as one of the finest of the Egyptian temples.

In 1903 the direotor commenced work on what at first appeared to be rnbbish heaps, but the magio touch of the spade brought to light a far older temple bnilt by Mentnhetep, a king of the eleventh dynasty,abont 2600 B.C., and it is chiefly from this edifice that tbe beautiful works of art which are now exhi- bited have been derived. The temple, like most of those in the Thebes, was the mortuary chapel of the king, and was bnilt roond a pyramidical strnotnre, beneath whioh was prob- ably the king’s grave. Riand this was an ambulatory adorned with beautiful sonlptnres, riohly coloured. On the other side of the enolo- anre were found the tombs of the priestesses of Hathor, who appear to have formed the royal harem, for they all bear "the title of favourite of the king." These tombs and the shrines were riohly deoorated, as were also the “tone coffins of the ladies ; and many of the best pieces of work here exhibited oome from these tombs. Lastly, there was a colonnade deoo- rated with soenea of war and the chase.

These sonlptnres and paintings restore to ns a long-lost and, it may be said, nnexpeoted chapter in Egyptian art It was thought that the fine work of the pyramid age had fallen into oblivion, but here is work even better ; and, what is more important, we are able to ascertain the name of the mastei who direuted and no donbt prodnoed mnoh of it There flourished in the region of Mentnhetep a certain sculptor named Mertisen, who tells ns on his tomb stone that “ha was a master of artistio skill, able to portray the human form and the movements of the limbs," and be was suc- ceeded by his equally clever son. These then are now, after nearly font thousand years, submitted to oar critioal inspection.

The method of the sohool was to work in high relief coloured to nature. The portraits of the king on the firet tablé are undoubted, and so is that of the queen, wlxr shows a dis- tinctly Ethiopian type of faee ; so are the family groups of the king, the queen, or the favour- ites. A wonderful pieoe of finished woik is a gronp with the Queen Aashait and the king wearing the white crown, which is repre- sented as made of fine grass-plaiting with the bands and orown of gold. The painted saroo- phaguB of the priestess Kemsit, a negress, is interesting becanse of the unfinished parts of the work, whioh showed how the artists drew out the design before ontting the relief and colouring it. Eqnally fine are the mi- litary scenes representing the wars against the Nomads of Sinai and Syria. The types of face are most perfect, while the weapons and oostames are a treasure to the arobre'o gist. A pretty little scene represents a youth, perhaps a prince, with his soribe or tutor behind him. Very spirited is a perfeot soulpture of a man gathering papyrns and tying it into bandies. These Egyptian artists were equally olese students of animal life, and there is great power in a desert hunt- ing soene and a touoh of hamonr in the fox robbing the nest of a bird from whioh the mother has Sown away. A orooodile oatohlng a fiih, and the somewhat onmbrons hippopo- tami are not worse works of art than those of many modern artists. All of these are correotly colonred.

Coming to later times, about 1200 b c there is a most interesting exhibition of workmen's tools, mallets, adzes, and ohisels, many speoi- ments of rope, inolnding a fender very like those used on the Counoii’s river steamers, and workmen’s tool and food baskets There is a splendid collection of the famous Egypt- ian bine glazed faience. The votive eyes and ears let in the Hathor Temple for the ocre of blindness and deafness are \ ary like the ex-votos of Lourdes and other shrines.

In February this year a most important dis- oovery was made of the iDviolate shrine of the goddess Hathor in the form of a cow, whioh was bnilt by Am,>D0phis II. The shrine has bean retained at Cairo, bat a model and several paietings are exhibited- The figure was ot life- size in limestone, painted reddish brown with black spots. Her neck is adorned with papyrus plants, and it evidently represents the Inner goddess coming ont of the mountain of the West, as shown by a vignette in the papyrns of Ani in the British Musenm. It is a wonder- ful piece of decorative work, and it is hoped that a model on a large scale may be obtained for thé British Musenm. ‘

A word mast be said for the work of M. Naviile and Mr. H. R. Hall, of the British Museum, who mainly contributed to the ga- thering ot this collection. The Fnnd hope to have sufficient funds this year subscribed to complete what it is no exaggeration to oall one of the most thorough works of exploration of modern times, and one which will show that the numerous workers iu the field of Egyptian arobæology are rescuing from tomb and temple the long-lost records of her history, art, and religion. The exhibition remains open until August 4th. W. St. Chad Bosoawen, in the "Tribune."

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: London, July 13.

In financial and monetary oiroles the past week has been one of higher interest than the □anal daily fiactnatione provide, as Lord Qosohen, the highest financial anthority living, has in a powerful speeoh (on the occasion of the 15th anniversary of the foundation of the National Discount Company, one of the greatest as well as the oldest discount busi- nesses in the world) baoked up his own old and Mr. Asquith’s new appeal for larger gold reserves by the Bank and the bankers. This appeal, which has been repeatedly made ever sinoe Mr. Bagehot’s "Lombard Street" pointed out the danger of the present system, oan no longer be disregarded.The public, indeed, have a right to insist that a fair proportion of their free deposits with the Banks Bhould go to safe- guard the general position,and that the bankers should not be over-greedy in getting large gains out of what ooBts them nothing in in- terest. To keep larger gold reserves than, so to speak, enough to weigh out the balanoes of trade, is economically unsound, and the policy pursued by other countries in locking up huge quantities of gold is one to be avoided, but the reserves should be ample. Of oourse, any farther gold reserves kept by the banks would deorease the amount of loanable oapital available for the market, and might oause stringency for some time. Just at present there seems to bs no fear of dear money so long ar the United States Treasury will look after the New York market. By today’s cables, we are assured ou this point by the statements made by the Secretary of the Treasury.

An important letter appears to-day in the ’ Times’’ from Sir Edward Law on the snbjeot of the present position of values of seonrities, pointing out the probable oause of the extra- ordinary depression of stocks. It is a pity that, in view of Sir E. Law's interest in the National Bank of Egypt, ss great an authority is not tbeaotive Lead of this important Bank, as suoh ar authority would be of great servioe to Egypt in many ways. A man of such oalibre in finance would be an invaluable aid to the Government by the advice he would be able to give. Sir Edward traces the main oause of the depression to the fluctuations of Consols and similar securities whioh have removed these from their former position as "Liquid assets.”

Although the Bank return shova a rise in the proportion of reserve to 48 as agaiDst 42 last week, there is no substantial addition to the available funds. At the same time, as- suming Amerioa will look after herself, there seems no reason why the demands should exceed the present supply.

The very small speculative aooonnt on the Stock Exchange at present shows no signs of augmentation. Unpleasant rumours have been afloat as regards an importnat banking firm, who have been taking reoent issues of first dess stooks, but we nnderstand that the dif- ficulties have been overoome, and that no farther trouble is likely to take place.

The Stock Exohange settlement this week has been an anxious one for its members. Tbe aooount had been notorious for the heavy depreciation in the value of securities, and the fears that the losses involved wonld plaoe more than one firm in a difficult position were duly realised. One important dealer in the West Afrioa market was “hammered” on Mon- day and in other oases arrangements with creditors had to be effeoted, several large ao- oounts being saved only at the last moment A jobber of 17 years' standing had a receiving order made against him, and he has ceased to be a member, Although pay-day passed without farther failures, it is felt that the troubles are not yet at an end.

This unsatisfactory state of things has kept markets at a tension during the week. It is true that on Wednesday, after the first dif- ficulties were overoome, a rather more con- fident tone was noticed, but this was short- lived, for with Thursday came an increase of anxiety, and dealings were praotioally nil. Prices fell all round, and the downward ten- dency has oontinned to-day.

it is believed, however, that when the rettle- ment troubles are got rid of, there w'll be a revival of ao'.ivity, and the firmness of gilt- edged stooks this week gives strength to this optimistio impression. The Home Bailway dividends, now almost due, are calculated to give a weloome impetus to business, while the splendid Band output for Jane oannot fail to have an excellent effect not only upon mining shares, but also on first-olaas securities. That the prosperity of trade continues in all parts of the country Is seen in the highly satisfactory Board of Trade returns published the other day and thus everything appears favourable for a return to active investment dealings.

The strength of the gilt edged market, in spite of the depression caused by the settle- ment, bas been ths gratifying feature of the week. The prioe of Consols has been over 88, and the dosing quotation to-night, 87 }§, shows an advance on the week of §. Other Govern- ment Funds are higher, the new Irish Land Loan being now firm at par.

The disappearance of the bear element oaused the international market to firm up at the beginning of the week, the improvement being reflected in the steadiness of Bussian bonds. The nervousness that bas sinoe dominated the House has, however, brought about a relapse, and yesterday the Pours were no better than 76They dose to-night at 76} and tbe New Loan at4discount. It is satisfactory to note that the anxiety oaused by Sir Edwatd Grey’s speech regarding the condition of Egypt has now evaporated, and Egyptian Unified have ad- vanced J to 105, and tbe Egyptian Preference Red. } to 102. Japanese have been irregular. The Second series of 4 } % have lost about 2} and the Fours }, but most of the other bonds are } better.

The home railway market also was the victim of yesterday’s attack of nerves, for previously tbe tonehd been firm, thongh the amount of business transacted was naturally limited. Nearly all the shares had advanoed, but in most oases the improvement has now been lost, though two or three lines yesterday gained from j to a point, while City and South London were no less than 1} higher.

The complete traffic returns for the half- year just ended Bhow a total increase for the ten chief lines amounting to £1,148,500, the only decrease being that of the London, Brigh- ton, and South Coast, whioh amounts to £2,000. The bulk of the gains are from the goods traffi is, these being a natural corollary of the splendid prosperity of the trade of the oountry. There are decreases in the passenger traffios of the Great Eastern and the London, Brighton, and South Coast amounting respect- ively to £1,500 and £10,900, but the Great Eastern more than make up the defioit by their goods traffio increase, while the Brighton line wipe off £8,900 of theft loss from tbe same source.

The new half-year has baen inaugurated with a batch of very satisfactory traffio gains, the North Eastern and Great Western being £14,000 and £10,000 to the good, while several of the other lines record increases of £5,003 to £9,COO.
Americans.

The Amerioan market has been unsteady, and yesterday prioes fell nearly all-round, there being several losses of 1}, while Unions, New York Central, and Readings deolined 2}, 2}, and 2} respectively. Chicago-Milwaukee, whioh hitherto had been well-supported, fell one point, and bave lost J to-day, the shares closing 2} up on the week. The latest prices to-night show a number of farther small de- clines in this market.

There is nothing to report in the market for Egyptian shares, prioes having soaroely moved. National Banks are a shade easier at 25}, bat Agricultural keep quite firm at 9}. Daira Sanieh, after being a bad matket at 16}, olose with a firmer tone at 17, tbe Deferred being unchanged at 97. Delta Land and Investment are supposed to be 3}, per- haps sellers, and Delta Preference have not been mentioned, these dosing 11}-12. Union Pondère are easier at 6, and Corporation of Western Egypt at -fa premium. Daira Sugar are better at 5} and Egyptian Estates at 1 H- Salt and Soda and Egyptian Markets are qnite dead as regards dealings, and dose at 1} and 1} respectively. Land Bank of Egypt are only 8| and Bink of Roumanie are quoted nominally 9}-10}. The new issue of Agricultural Bank guaranteed Debentures are offered at 1} disoount, without finding any boyars. Khédivial Mail Ordinary are 1}-}, and the Preference 4} }.
Mining.

The record gold return of the Band for last month was warmly welcomed in the South Afrioan market, bnt even this good influence oould not long prevail against the general weakness and ths rumours of native trou- bles, and farther liquidation followed yester- day. Band Mines fell} to 5 91/32 and East Bands and Goldfislds 3/31 to 3 23/32 and 3 7/32. These shares have had alight declines again to-day, and dose flat.

Egyptian Options seem to be the only shares that have been dealt in the Egyptian section, the quotation having risen } to 1}. Eryptian-Mines Exploration have declined to 2s. Th:re are no other ohanges to reoord.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
